Message.Title: Yahoo is unravelling. The Products are unravelling and do not work. Not functional. Nobody is home or calls you back
Message.Msg: Disappointing. If the basic product sets are any indication of the company then Yahoo is falling apart. They have yet to make a functional Calendar. You can not add events and then see them or edit them. This is only a partial list. They have not made yahoo functional on one of the most popular browsers Mozilla Firefox. Yahoo mail was down for about 5 months and not functional even after I sent in five complaints. When you put in a request to fix a problem nobody calls you back. If you want to get rich then build a company exactly like the Yahoo of 10 years ago that had working products and common sense products. I always offer solutions and not just a message board #$%$. I will be glad to fly out to yahoo as a consultant and fix all their problems on the house. Yahoo user of 10 years but ready to go somewhere else. Feel free to hire me Yahoo to return you to a great company. I have plenty of solutions and new ideas for your failing organization.

Message.Title: Yahoo's hedg against the Yen 380$ million pay-off for yahoo
Message.Msg: for next quarter eannings .

Topic.Title: Yahoo's hedg against the Yen 380$ million pay-off for yahoo

Message.Msg: Yahoo ’s new hedge-fund expertise is paying off — perhaps to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars. The company’s 35% stake in Yahoo Japan , worth around $6.5 billion at year-end, had risen over 70% through Friday in local currency terms. Too bad the local currency has had a notably rougher go of it, falling 12% against the dollar thanks to the Bank of Japan’s plan to print yen to fight deflation. In dollar terms, then, Yahoo’s stake in Yahoo Japan is up closer to 50%. Lucky for Yahoo, board member Daniel Loeb saw it coming. Noting new Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s zeal to devalue, Mr. Loeb’s hedge fund Third Point put on a short position against the yen last fall according to a recent investor letter. In December and January, Yahoo did the same, entering forward contracts with a notional value of $3.2 billion to hedge the value of its Yahoo Japan stake. It’s not far-fetched to believe Mr. Loeb had something to do with that. The yen’s subsequent decline means those contracts are likely to have paid off nicely, perhaps as much $380 million through Friday. Any gains won’t impact the company’s reported earnings, which will be reported Tuesday. Instead they’ll show up as an increase in the cash balance when the contracts close. An extra $380 million would equate to more than 30 cents per share. That’s not bad considering Yahoo is expected to report earnings of just $0.25 per share in the first quarter.

Message.Title: SHOCK: My Ignorant Forcast
Message.Msg: Stop the press, here is my best understanding of tomorrow’s revenue (ex-TAC): Premises: CPC decreased 5% in Bing/Yahoo net, Display Price-Per-Ad increased 5%, Display ads numbers comes from Comscore total users, Search comes from Comscore search. •Q4-12 Display Ads x Growth total users x Price-Per-Ad Increase = $520M x 1.0808 x 1.05 = $ 590.12M •Q4 12-Search Ads x Growth search x CPC Decrease = $427Mx1.0743 x .95 = $ 435.80M • Plus Other $250 for a Total of $1.276B, consensus is $1.106B, 15.36 % over consensus. Any better calculation?

Topic.Title: Hunter Orr downgrades Yahoo to sell! Ouch if your long ....

Message.Msg: http://finance.yahoo.com/q/rr?s=YHOO+Research+Reports Copy and paste that link and you will see...It's right there in black and white dude. If your a serious investor or trader you would have dug it up like I did instead of blindly surfing these Yahoo chat boards. These guys are nothing but cheerleaders of the stock. There is no Apple talks. That was a rumor to drive up the price and the big boys who knew that unloaded at nice prices. These things happen a lot. It was easy for me to see and that's why I increased my short position the last few days. I even shorted more just after the open. It' was obvious we have seen the blowoff top occur these last 3-4 days. But today was the big reversal and it's going to be a painful next week or so if you are long. Hunter Orr looks like he basically called the top again. He has done this countless other times but he doesn't get the credo he deserves. The big investment banks don't like him but they do react to what he says.

Message.Title: Yahoo’s Yen Hedge Earns $380 Million in Cash
Message.Msg: Yahoo’s new hedge-fund expertise is paying off — perhaps to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars. The company’s 35% stake in Yahoo Japan, worth around $10 billion at year-end, had risen over 70% through Friday in local currency terms. Too bad the local currency has had a notably rougher go of it, falling 12% against the dollar thanks to the Bank of Japan’s plan to print yen to fight deflation. In dollar terms, then, Yahoo’s stake in Yahoo Japan is up closer to 50%. Lucky for Yahoo, board member Daniel Loeb saw it coming. Noting new Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s zeal to devalue, Mr. Loeb’s hedge fund Third Point put on a short position against the yen last fall according to a recent investor letter. In December and January, Yahoo did the same, entering forward contracts with a notional value of $3.2 billion to hedge the value of its Yahoo Japan stake. It’s not far-fetched to believe Mr. Loeb had something to do with that. The yen’s subsequent decline means those contracts are likely to have paid off nicely, perhaps as much $380 million through Friday. Any gains won’t impact the company’s reported earnings, which will be reported Tuesday. Instead they’ll show up as an increase in the cash balance when the contracts close. An extra $380 million would equate to more than 30 cents per share. That’s not bad considering Yahoo is expected to report earnings of just $0.25 per share in the first quarter.
